body:
Do I need to update my MLFlow package?

do you mean this:
```
In [21]: # MLflow < 2.0

In [22]: print("MLflow version:", mlflow.__version__)
MLflow version: 1.30.0

In [23]: print("Tracking URI:", mlflow.get_tracking_uri())
Tracking URI: file:///C:/xx/mlruns

In [24]: print("Artifact URI:", mlflow.get_artifact_uri())
Artifact URI: file:///C:/xx/mlruns/0/6c9c5a3a5f274fbdbeb80599a626809d/artifacts

In [25]:

In [25]: # MLflow >= 2.0

In [26]: mlflow.doctor()
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
AttributeError                            Traceback (most recent call last)
Input In [26], in <cell line: 1>()
----> 1 mlflow.doctor()

AttributeError: module 'mlflow' has no attribute 'doctor'

In [27]: Traceback (most recent call last):
    ...:       File "<string>", line 7, in <module>
  Input In [27]
    Traceback (most recent call last):
                    ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax


In [28]: AttributeError: module 'mlflow' has no attribute 'doctor'
```

Wait

```
In [24]: print("Artifact URI:", mlflow.get_artifact_uri())
Artifact URI: file:///C:/xx/mlruns/0/6c9c5a3a5f274fbdbeb80599a626809d/artifacts
```

This looks strange.

At the moment, I am actually more interested to save the tracking data in a remote server. 
I guess I should use this command to set the tracking data in a remote server?
```
mlflow.set_tracking_uri("sqlite:///ip_address/xx/mlruns/mlflow.db")
```

As an alternative, do you have a sample code that sets up a docker image running in a remote Linux server? I kind of gave up the windows sftp server.

@YJonmo

> I guess I should use this command to set the tracking data in a remote server?

Yes!

> do you have a sample code that sets up a docker image running in a remote Linux server? I kind of gave up the windows sftp server.

https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/tree/master/examples/mlflow_artifacts might help. Let me know if you need a simpler example.
@WeichenXu123 The `mlflow.doctor` failure is unrelated to the issue. We can ignore it.

Thanks for the quick reply.
Right now I am trying to do something very simple: set the backend to a remote Ubuntu server. So I run these few lines:
Remote:
```
mlflow server --port 5000 --host xxx.xx.xx.xx
```
client:
```
import mlflow
mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://jacob:password@xxx.xxx.xx.xx:/home/jacob/Downloads")
mlflow.start_run()
```
but I get this error:
```
WARNI [urllib3.connectionpool] Retrying (Retry(total=4, connect=4, read=5, redirect=5, status=5)) after connection broken by 'NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.HTTPConnection object at 0x7f41e3f4a460>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno 113] No route to host')': /home/jacob/Downloads/api/2.0/mlflow/runs/create
```
similarly if I want to use sqlite:
```
mlflow.set_tracking_uri("sqlite:///jacob:password@xxx.xx.xx.xx:/home/jacob/Downloads/data.db")
mlflow.start_run()
```
I will get the following error:
```
2022/12/05 13:15:45 WARNING mlflow.store.db.utils: SQLAlchemy engine could not be created. The following exception is caught.
(sqlite3.OperationalError) unable to open database file
(Background on this error at: http://sqlalche.me/e/14/e3q8)
Operation will be retried in 0.1 seconds
```

Is the syntax correct for setting the remote backend for tracking the parameters? 
remote = Ubuntu
Client = WSL:Ubuntu

I think a URL for sqlite must a local file path:

https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/20/core/engines.html#sqlite

> SQLite connects to file-based databases, using the Python built-in module sqlite3 by default. As SQLite connects to local files, the URL format is slightly different. The “file” portion of the URL is the filename of the database. For a relative file path, this requires three slashes:

You can run this command in your remote server:

```
mlflow server --backend-store-uri sqlite:///path/to/data.db ...
```

then run:

```python
import mlflow

mlflow.set_tracking_uri("xxx.xx.xx.xx")
```

Thank you but I want to have a remote server (an Ubuntu machine) where I and others use to log (backend) their mlruns.
I don't necessarily need sqlite. I was just using sqlite as an example.  
Is such a thing possible to use a remote linux or windows for backend while clients are our local machines? 
I saw others having the same question with no concrete solution at the end like issue [572 ](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/issues/572 )

Yes. You can just run this on your server:

```
mlflow server
```

and run this on your local machine:

```python
import mlflow

mlflow.set_tracking_uri("xxx.xx.xx.xx")

with mlflow.start_run():
    mlflow.log_artifact("/path/to/file")
```

The artifact should be logged in your remote server.

Thanks for the reply.

I might be doing a simple mistake somewhere as I am new to MLFlow. 

So I did this: 
for the **server**:
```
PS C:\> mlflow server
INFO:waitress:Serving on http://127.0.0.1:5000
```
then in the **client**, I tried these:
```
import mlflow
mlflow.set_tracking_uri("xxx.xx.xx.xx")   # xxx.xx.xx.xx is the IP address of the remote  
mlflow.start_run()                                  
```
but it creates the folder xxx.xx.xx.xx in local machine!  
Instead I tried:
```
mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://xxx.xx.xx.xx")
mlflow.start_run()   
```
but it hangs there and doesn't do anything.
Finally, I tried:
```
mlflow.set_tracking_uri("http://127.0.0.1:5000")
```
also hanged there and did nothing and after a while it came with this message:
```
MlflowException: API request to http://127.0.0.1:5000/api/2.0/mlflow/runs/create failed with exception HTTPConnectionPool(host='127.0.0.1', port=5000): Max retries exceeded with url: /api/2.0/mlflow/runs/create (Caused by NewConnectionError('<urllib3.connection.HTTPConnection object at 0x7f5f1d52a040>: Failed to establish a new connection: [Errno 111] Connection refused'))
```

Please let me know if I am doing something wrong here. 
By the way, I am using VPN to communicate between the two computers.

Yes I did and it also hung and did nothing.
Could it be the server's firewall blocking the port connection?
